_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ONEOK Rockies Midstream, L.L.C. (ORM - Owner/Operator)

MARMARTH GAS PLANT



ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



ONEOK Rockies Midstream, L.L.C. (ORM) has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, gas plant trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.  The following is a statement from ONEOK Partners, L.P. (ONEOK - Parent Company) Senior Management.  ONEOK believes in maintaining a safe working environment for all employees.  Our equipment and personnel reflect this belief, and our prime objective is to ensure the personal safety of every employee on the job-site and to safe guard company property through preventative measures.  Employees of ORM are expected to be familiar with all company safety policies.  Through continuing education, in-house training and management support, we will provide a safe and professional working environment for our employees as well as those whose lives and safety have been entrusted to us.



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



The Marmarth Gas Plant (Facility), located in Slope County, North Dakota, uses refrigerated fractionation to process wellhead gas into marketable natural gas and natural gas liquids (NGL).  As a result of this operation, several EPA regulated flammable substances are processed, recovered, and stored at the facility (e.g. methane, ethane, propane, butane, pentane, and natural gas condensate).  There is approximately 490,000 lbs of flammable product stored in various tanks on site.  The Marmarth Gas Plant does not use or store any regulated toxic substances above the EPA set threshold leve

ls.  The facility is unmanned.



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS



Not Required



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Marmarth Gas Plant complies with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule with all applicable state codes and regulations.  The gas plant was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA, API, ASME, and other codes and regulations.  All of our operators have been thoroughly trained in facility operation, safety, process hazards, and emergency response.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



We investigate every incident very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from recurring.  We have had NO releases, associated with the facility EPA regulated substances that resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place for the last five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The Marmarth Gas Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The ERP consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion.  ORM employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  If an emergency were to occur, the facility ERP provides instructions to employees for notification of the local fire authority, Slope County Fire Departments and Sheriff's office.



The ERP is updated when necessary based on modifications to the Marmarth Gas Plant operation or equipment, changes in receptors or responders.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



ORM recognizes the value of the PSM standard as a way of safely conducting their business operations.  Therefore, we are continuously implementin
g the PSM elements to our Non-PSM regulated processes and facilities.  We are also continuing to improve our training program and training records.
